intro: Elettaria punicea, commonly known as cardamom, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the tropical regions of South and Southeast Asia. It belongs to the ginger family (Zingiberaceae) and is characterized by its aromatic, spindle-shaped rhizomes that produce the spice cardamom. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters, with broad, lance-shaped leaves and clusters of small, pale green flowers. After flowering, it produces elongated, three-lobed fruits that contain the aromatic seeds used as a spice. The essential oils in the seeds contribute to its distinctive flavor and medicinal properties.
